Original question: Explain the following observation: cells of E. coli fermenting glucose grow faster when NO - is supplied to the culture, and then grow even faster when the culture is highly aerated.
Solution: When E. coli is growing in a fermentative mode, there is no external electron receptor and the energy yield is low. When NO - is added to the culture, nitrate acts as an electron receptor. Under these 3 respiratory conditions the energy yield is greater than fermentative conditions but still less than when O2 is the final electron receptor (aerobic)
